Lymphoedema

What does this physical condition?

Lymphedema is an increase of the volume that can occur in any part of the body and is caused by a defect in the lymphatic system.The origin of lymphedema varies depending on whether it is primary or secondary. When we talk about the lymphatic system, we refer to the network of tissues and organs distributed throughout the body that is responsible for cleaning waste. It has a superficial part, located just under the skin, and a deeper part, next to the vascular and nervous system.

Let's create something amazing together!

What can cause lymphedema?

Lymphedema can occur because the lymphatic system has been damaged after surgery, it has been burned when a patient undergoes radiotherapy, when lymph nodes are removed to prevent the spread of a tumor or because they were invaded, when the lymphatic system is obstructed by a mass, or in underdeveloped countries, by filariasis, a disease caused by the bite of a mosquito that then obstructs the lymphatic system.

All these lymphedemas are secondary and there is a cause, almost always oncological, in developed countries.

Primary lymphedemas are those caused by a birth defect in the lymphatic system, when a person is born with fewer vessels or nodes than normal, or they are smaller and cannot perform all the cleaning work for which they are programmed.
